input:
1. A 14-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with a history of progressive numbness and tingling in his hands and feet since early childhood. His parents report frequent injuries to his fingers and toes, which often go unnoticed and become infected. On examination, he has absent pain and temperature sensation in a glove-and-stocking distribution but preserved vibration and proprioception. Muscle strength is normal, but he demonstrates decreased deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. He also has early signs of painless skin ulcers and bone deformities in his feet, consistent with Charcot arthropathy. Family history reveals a maternal uncle with similar symptoms but no definitive diagnosis. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the SPTLC2 gene, consistent with hereditary sensory neuropathy type Ie. Supportive management including wound care, protective footwear, and physical therapy is initiated to prevent further complications.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: I'm a bit nervous, but I need to tell the doctor what's been going on. I keep feeling weird tingly stuff in my hands and feet, and it's been happening for a long time. Sometimes I get scared about hurting myself and not noticing.

ANSWER: Um, I guess I just... I feel these weird numb and tingling feelings in my hands and feet, and it’s been happening pretty much forever. I keep worried I might hurt myself but I don't always notice until it’s too late. It’s kind of been getting worse lately, I think.

input: 1. A 14-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with a history of progressive numbness and tingling in his hands and feet since early childhood. His parents report frequent injuries to his fingers and toes, which often go unnoticed and become infected. On examination, he has absent pain and temperature sensation in a glove-and-stocking distribution but preserved vibration and proprioception. Muscle strength is normal, but he demonstrates decreased deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. He also has early signs of painless skin ulcers and bone deformities in his feet, consistent with Charcot arthropathy. Family history reveals a maternal uncle with similar symptoms but no definitive diagnosis. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the SPTLC2 gene, consistent with hereditary sensory neuropathy type Ie. Supportive management including wound care, protective footwear, and physical therapy is initiated to prevent further complications.Can you tell me more about how these numbness and tingling sensations have been changing over time and if there are any other symptoms or situations that seem to make them better or worse?
output: Um, it's been sorta gradually getting worse, I think. Sometimes, it feels really numb and kinda tingly all over my hands and feet, like pins and needles, and it doesn’t seem to go away. I haven't noticed much that helps or makes it worse, honestly. It just kind of feels the same most of the time, but sometimes it gets a little worse when I’m tired or if I accidentally hurt myself without realizing.

input: 1. A 14-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with a history of progressive numbness and tingling in his hands and feet since early childhood. His parents report frequent injuries to his fingers and toes, which often go unnoticed and become infected. On examination, he has absent pain and temperature sensation in a glove-and-stocking distribution but preserved vibration and proprioception. Muscle strength is normal, but he demonstrates decreased deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. He also has early signs of painless skin ulcers and bone deformities in his feet, consistent with Charcot arthropathy. Family history reveals a maternal uncle with similar symptoms but no definitive diagnosis. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the SPTLC2 gene, consistent with hereditary sensory neuropathy type Ie. Supportive management including wound care, protective footwear, and physical therapy is initiated to prevent further complications.Can you tell me more about how these sensations have been affecting you day-to-day, and whether you've noticed any other changes or new symptoms happening recently?
output: Well, it's kinda hard to explain, but my hands and feet feel numb and tingly all the time, and sometimes I don’t really notice if I hurt myself until it’s worse. Lately, I feel like my toes and fingers get worse, and I worry because I don’t feel pain when I get cuts or bumps. It’s been making everything more difficult, and I keep worrying about if it’s going to get any worse.

Supportive management including wound care, protective footwear, and physical therapy is initiated to prevent further complications."Beyond the numbness and tingling, are there any other changes you've noticed, like weakness, difficulty walking, balance issues, or any systemic symptoms such as fatigue, weight changes, or vision problems?"
output: Um, I don’t really feel weak or anything like that, but I guess sometimes I feel a little wobbly, like I might trip over stuff I used to do fine. I don’t really notice anything with my vision or feeling super tired or anything, but I dunno, sometimes I just feel kinda off, but I can't really say why.
